title: Theo Holm
text:
Herman Theodor "Theo" Holm (February 3, 1854 - December 26, 1932) was a Danish-American <a href="systematics">systematic</a> <a href="botanist">botanist</a>, agriculturalist and plant pathologist. His works dealt principally with plants from the <a href="Arctic">Arctic</a> and from the <a href="Rocky%20Mountains">Rocky Mountains</a>, mainly <a href="Taxonomy%20%28biology%29">taxonomy</a> and <a href="Morphology%20%28biology%29">morphology</a>. He published over 150 papers reflecting his research which included his series "Studies on the <a href="Cyperaceae">Cyperaceae</a>" and "Medicinal Plants of North America". 
Biography.
Herman Theodor Holm was born in <a href="Copenhagen%2C%20Denmark">Copenhagen, Denmark</a>. 
He studied <a href="botany">botany</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Copenhagen">University of Copenhagen</a> under professor <a href="Eugenius%20Warming">Eugenius Warming</a> and graduated 1880. In 1882–1883, he participated in the expedition on board the Danish vessel "Dijmphna" ("Dijmphna-expeditionen 1882-83") to the territory between <a href="Russia">Russia</a> and the <a href="North%20Pole">North Pole</a> during the First <a href="International%20Polar%20Year">International Polar Year</a>. The ship was icebound for a period in the <a href="Kara%20Sea">Kara Sea</a>.
He also explored the flora of West <a href="Greenland">Greenland</a> as assistant to Eugenius Warming on the "<a href="Carl%20Ryder">Fylla expedition</a>" in 1884. 
He emigrated to the U.S., landing in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> on April 12, 1888. He soon was employed as assistant botanist by the <a href="National%20Museum%20of%20Natural%20History">U.S. National Museum</a>. In 1893 when he received American citizenship. From 1893 to 1897, he was assistant pathologist with the <a href="United%20States%20Department%20of%20Agriculture">United States Department of Agriculture</a> (USDA). He obtained his Ph.D. in botany from the <a href="Catholic%20University%20of%20America">Catholic University of America</a> in <a href="Washington%20D.C.">Washington D.C.</a> in 1902. He then moved to the countryside of Brookland, DC and later in Clinton, <a href="Maryland">Maryland</a> and did assistant work as a botanist for the <a href="Smithsonian%20Institution">Smithsonian Institution</a> and the USDA. Although a <a href="Lutheran">Lutheran</a>, in 1932 he joined the faculty of the <a href="Catholic%20University%20of%20America">Catholic University of America</a>, but died soon after.
Honors.
The small-reed species "<a href="Calamagrostis">Calamagrostis holmii</a>" <a href="Johan%20Lange">Lange</a> is named for him.
